The '''Taught Course Centre''' or '''TCC''' is a collaboration between the [[mathematics]] departments at five UK [[universities]] aimed at providing a broader range of lecture courses for postgraduate students.
==Members==
The five collaborating universities are: *[[University of Bath]] *[[University of Bristol]] *[[Imperial College London]] *[[University of Oxford]] *[[University of Warwick]]
Lectures are given at all five universities and, using [[Access Grid]] technology, students at each of the other four institutes may participate with each lecture.
The TCC was set up in 2007 with funding from the [[EPSRC]]. Twenty six courses were made available to students in the first year of the collaboration, with topics from diverse areas of mathematics including [[number theory]], [[partial differential equations]], [[random matrix theory]], and [[group theory]]. One of the aims of the project was to encourage contact between postgraduate mathematics students at the five universities and set up future collaborative work.
==Configuration== In normal operation, the TCC uses [[Access Grid|access grid]] technology for video conferencing using the proprietary [[IOCOM]] software suite. The lectures take place in the [[Virtual Venue Server|virtual venue]] named ''Maths TCC''. These lectures may be recorded upon request if permission from participants is obtained in advance.
TCC lectures normally transmit video streams using [[H.261]] and audio as [[G.711]] for compatibility with the freely available AG3 software.
Each Access Grid session is paired with a [[Extensible Messaging and Presence Protocol|Jabber/XMPP]] session on the Access Grid Support Centre (AGSC) [[Virtual Venue Server]]. The XMPP session allows instant messaging with other participants allowing fault diagnosis or communication without interrupting a session.
===Oxford=== The Oxford TCC is equipped with a [[Smart Board]] and [[Smart Technologies|Sympodium]] that can be viewed locally and transmitted to all participants of the meeting.
==Events== * January 21, 2008 : TCC Number Theory Event Day was held at Bristol and students were given a chance to talk about their research to their peers and share ideas.
* May 21, 2013 : Graduate TCC Conference in Number Theory was a successful continuation of the aforementioned event.
==See also== *[[MAGIC (postgraduate mathematics)]] a similar project with a different group of UK universities *[[IOCOM]]
==External links== *[http://tcc.maths.ox.ac.uk/ The TCC website] *[https://www.maths.bris.ac.uk/events/meetings/meeting/index.php?meeting_id=102 The Graduate TCC Conference in Number Theory website]

web|url=http://blogs.amctv.com/the-walking-dead/2010/08/premiere-comic-con-trailer-video.php|title=''The Walking Dead'' Premieres Halloween; Comic-Con Trailer Now Online|work=AMCtv.com|date=August 24, press|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news/2010/11/08/amc-resurrects-the-walking-dead-for-a-second-season-639014/20101108amc01/|title=AMC Resurrects "The Walking Dead" for a Second fall's biggest rating |work=Entertainment Weekly |first=James |last=Hibberd |date=October 15, 2012 |accessdate=October 15, 2012}} ===''Fear the Walking Dead''=== {{main|Fear the Walking Dead}} ''Fear the Walking Dead'' is an American [[horror fiction|horror]] [[drama]] television series created by [[Robert Kirkman]] and [[Dave Erickson]], acting as a [[Spin-off (media)|companion series]] and [[prequel]] to ''[[The Walking Dead (TV series)|The Walking Dead]]''.{{cite web |url=https://variety.com/2015/tv/features/fear-the-walking-dead-preview-amc-1201556500/ |title=‘Fear the Walking Dead’ Cast and Creators Talk Kickstarting the Apocalypse |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |first=Laura |last=Prudom |date=August 5, 2015 |accessdate=August 12, 2015}} The series premiered on [[AMC (TV channel)|AMC]] on August 23, 2015,{{cite web |url=http://tvline.com/2015/07/10/fear-the-walking-dead-trailer-season-1-spinoff-video/ |title=''Fear the Walking Dead'' Trailer Is Finally Here! (And So's the Premiere Date!) |publisher=TVLine |first=Michael |last=Slezak |date=July 10, 2015 |accessdate=July 10, 2015}} and it has been renewed for a third season to air in 2017;{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2016/04/15/fear-walking-dead-renewed-season-3|title=Fear the Walking Dead renewed for season 3|date=April 15, 2016|work=Entertainment Weekly|first=Dan|last=Snierson|accessdate=April 15, 2016}} as well as been renewed for a fourth season on April 14 2017, before the season three premiere.{{Cite web|url=http://tvline.com/2017/04/14/fear-the-walking-dead-renewed-season-4-amc-new-showrunners/|title=Fear the Walking Dead Renewed for Season 4, New Showrunners Named|last=Nemetz|first=Dave|last2=Nemetz|first2=Dave|date=2017-04-14|website=TVLine|access-date=2017-04-14}}. In July 2018 the show was renewed for a fifth season set to air in 2019. Set initially in [[Los Angeles|Los Angeles, California]], the series follows a dysfunctional family composed of high school guidance counselor [[Madison Clark]], her boyfriend and English teacher [[Travis Manawa]], her daughter Alicia, and her drug-addicted son Nick, at the onset of the zombie apocalypse.{{cite web|title=Cast|url=http://www.amc.com/shows/fear-the-walking-dead/cast-crew|publisher=AMC|accessdate=August 25, 2015}}{{cite news |last=Cohn |first=Paulette |date=August 25, 2015|publisher=Fox News |title='Fear the Walking Dead' producer: Prequel hit about 'dread, the anxiety, and paranoia' |url=http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2015/08/25/fear-walking-dead-producer-hit-show-about-dread-anxiety-and-paranoia/ |accessdate=August 25, 2015}} The four must either revamp themselves or cling to their deep flaws as they come to terms with the impending collapse of civilization.{{cite web|title=About the Show|url=http://www.amc.com/shows/fear-the-walking-dead/exclusives/about|publisher=AMC|accessdate=August 25, 2015}} ===Untitled spin-off=== In July 2018, during [[San Diego Comic Con]], executive producer [[Scott Gimple]] announced that a new spin-off is in the works.{{cite web|url=http://comicbook.com/thewalkingdead/2018/07/21/the-walking-dead-spinoff-comic-con-scott-gimple|title=‘The Walking Dead’ Executive Producer Planning Another Spinoff|website=comicbook.com|date=July 21, 2018}} ==Films== In November 2018, [[Scott Gimple]] confirmed on [[Talking Dead]] that three AMC Original Films of The Walking Dead are in development with [[Andrew Lincoln]] signed on the reprise his role as [[Rick Grimes]], which the films would be focused on after his exit on the [[The Walking Dead (TV series)|television series]]. [[Pollyanna McIntosh]] will reprise her role of [[Jadis (The Walking Dead)|Jadis]]. Production on the film is set to begin in 2019.{{cite web|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/amp/live-feed/walking-dead-expansion-plans-revealed-andrew-lincoln-movies-new-series-come-1157921|title='Walking Dead' Expansion Plans Revealed: Andrew Lincoln to Lead 3 AMC Movies|website=hollywoodreporter|date=November 5, 2018}} ==Web series== ===''The Walking Dead: Torn Apart''=== {{main|The Walking Dead: Torn Apart}} ''The Walking Dead: Torn Apart'' is a six-part [[web series]] based on the television series ''[[The Walking Dead (TV series)|The Walking Dead]]''. It aired in its entirety on October 3, 2011, on [[AMC (TV channel)|AMC]]'s official website. The web series tells the origin story of Hannah, also known as "Bicycle Girl", the walker whom [[Rick Grimes]] killed in the [[Days Gone Bye (The Walking Dead)|first episode]].{{cite press|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news/2011/09/27/amc-launches-the-walking-dead-webisodes-on-monday-october-3-at-2-pm-801410/20110927amc01/|title=AMC Launches "The Walking Dead" Webisodes on Monday, October 3 at 2 PM|publisher=AMC|date=September 27, 2011|accessdate=September 27, 2011}} Rick risks a walker encounter to go back and find Hannah before he sets out for Atlanta. After telling her he is "sorry this happened to you," Rick shoots her in what is clearly a humanitarian gesture, which reveals much about Rick's own character and sets a tone for the rest of season one. ===''The Walking Dead: Cold Storage''=== {{main|The Walking Dead: Cold Storage}} ''The Walking Dead: Cold Storage'' is a four-part [[web series]] based on the television series ''[[The Walking Dead (TV series)|The Walking Dead]]''. It aired in its entirety on October 1, 2012, on [[AMC (TV channel)|AMC]]'s official website, two weeks before the premiere of the [[The Walking Dead (season 3)|third season]] of the show. The web series follows the story of a young man named Chase as he seeks shelter in a storage facility commanded by a malicious employee named B.J.{{cite press|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2012/10/01/the-walking-dead-new-webisodes-launch-on-amctv-com-on-monday-october-1/150796/|title='The Walking Dead' New Webisodes Launch on AMCTV.com on Monday, October 1|first=Sara|last=Bibel|publisher=[[Tribune Digital Ventures]]|work=[[TV by the Numbers]]|date=October 1, 2012|accessdate=September 20, 2015}}{{Cite web|url=http://blogs.amctv.com/the-walking-dead/2012/10/season-3-webisodes.php|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121002223953/http://blogs.amctv.com/the-walking-dead/2012/10/season-3-webisodes.php|archivedate=October 2, 2012|title=''The Walking Dead – Cold Storage'' Webisodes Now Online|publisher=AMCtv.com|last=Neuman|first=Clayton|date=October 1, 2012|accessdate=September 20, 2015}} This web series marks a second installment, following ''[[The Walking Dead: Torn Apart]]'', which aired a year earlier.{{cite press|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news/2011/09/27/amc-launches-the-walking-dead-webisodes-on-monday-october-3-at-2-pm-801410/20110927amc01/|title=AMC Launches "The Walking Dead" Webisodes on Monday, October 3 at 2 PM|publisher=Futon Media|work=[[The Futon Critic]]|date=September 27, 2011|accessdate=October 14, 2012}} ===''The Walking Dead: The Oath''=== {{main|The Walking Dead: The Oath}} ''The Walking Dead: The Oath'' is a three-part [[web series]] based on the television series ''[[The Walking Dead (TV series)|The Walking Dead]]''. It aired in its entirety on October 1, 2013, on [[AMC (TV channel)|AMC]]'s official website. This series tells the origin of the "Don't Open, Dead Inside" paint on the cafeteria doors of the hospital Rick Grimes awakes in, post-apocalypse. It follows Paul and Karina as they escape their zombie-overrun camp in search of a medical station. The central theme of the series examines the will to persevere in the face of inevitable death.{{Cite web|url=http://blogs.amctv.com/the-walking-dead/2013/10/the-walking-dead-the-oath-webisodes-now-available-online/|title=''The Walking Dead – The Oath'' Webisodes Now Available Online|publisher=AMC|first=Clayton|last=Neuman|date=October 1, 2013|accessdate=October 1, 2013}} ===''Fear the Walking Dead: Flight 462''=== {{main|Fear the Walking Dead: Flight 462}} ''Fear The Walking Dead: Flight 462'' is a 16-part [[web series]] based on the television series ''[[Fear the Walking Dead]]''. The series premiered on October 4, 2015, on [[AMC (TV channel)|AMC]]'s official website. The web series tells the story of a group of passengers aboard a commercial airplane during the earliest moments of the outbreak. Over the course of the series, the plane and the lives of its passengers are put in jeopardy once they discover an infected traveler. Two of its characters, Alex and Jake, are introduced in ''Fear the Walking Dead'' season 2, episode 3 "Ouroboros".{{cite web |url=http://deadline.com/2015/09/fear-the-walking-dead-flight-462-web-series-premiere-date-1201554908/ |title='Fear The Walking Dead: Flight 462' Web Series Gets Premiere Date |publisher=Deadline.com |first=Denise |last=Petski |date=September 28, 2015 |accessdate=September 28, 2015}} === ''Fear the Walking Dead: Passage'' === {{main|List of Fear the Walking Dead episodes#Fear the Walking Dead: Passage}} A second 16-part web series, debuted on October 17, 2016, and episodes were made available online weekly and aired as promos during the seventh season of ''The Walking Dead''. The web series follows Sierra, a capable survivor, who helps an injured woman named Gabi. ===''The Walking Dead: Red Machete''=== {{main|The Walking Dead: Red Machete}} A six-part webisode series entitled ''Red Machete'' first premiered on October 22, 2017. The web series tells the origin story of [[Rick Grimes]]'s red machete. The series starred actors Jose Rosete, Anais Lilit, Sofia Esmaili,{{cite web|url=https://dailydead.com/watch-the-first-installment-of-new-digital-series-the-walking-dead-red-machete/|title=Watch the First Installment of New Digital Series THE WALKING DEAD RED MACHETE|publisher=Daily Dead|first=Derek|last=Anderson|date=October 22, 2017|accessdate=February 3, 2018}} and [[Jeff Kober]], reprising his role as Joe, the leader of the Claimers from the fourth season of ''The Walking Dead''.{{cite web |url=http://toofab.com/2017/12/10/the-walking-dead-red-machete-web-series-rick-series-crossover-the-claimers/ |title=AMC's 'Walking Dead' Web Series Finally Crosses Over With Main Show |website=TooFab plans to release a tabletop miniature wargame based on ''The Walking Dead'', named ''The Walking Dead: All Out War''. ===Video games=== ====Telltale Games==== {{main|The Walking Dead (video game series)}} =====''The Walking Dead: Season One''===== {{main|The Walking Dead (video game)}} On February 18, 2011, [[Telltale Games]] announced plans to create an [[episodic video game]] based on the comics,Schram, Kevin. [http://nexus404.com/Blog/2011/02/18/the-walking-dead-video-game-coming-from-telltale-games-adventure-game-makers-announce-zombie-adventure-game-have-big-day-today-in-all/ "The Walking Dead Video Game Coming From Telltale Games [Adventure Game Makers Announce Zombie Adventure Game, Have Big Day Today In All]"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120318115717/http://nexus404.com/Blog/2011/02/18/the-walking-dead-video-game-coming-from-telltale-games-adventure-game-makers-announce-zombie-adventure-game-have-big-day-today-in-all/ |date=2012-03-18 }}, TFTS, February 18, 2011 was scheduled to debut in fall 2011, but finally was released on April 24, 2012.[http://www.telltalegames.com/walkingdead Telltale Games: The Walking Dead] Kirkman has said that, unlike typical zombie games such as ''[[Left 4 Dead]]'', it focuses more on characterization and emotion than action. The video game includes known characters and also introduces characters not shown in the comic or TV show.[http://insidetv.ew.com/2011/03/02/walking-dead-season-two-details/ Robert Kirkman on 'Walking Dead' season two: 'You haven't seen anything yet'] From April 24, 2012 to November 20, 2012, the game released five episodes, and then released a [[400 Days (video game)|DLC Pack]] in June 2013. The game was met with critical acclaim, winning several [[Game of the Year]] awards. =====''The Walking Dead: Season Two''===== {{main|The Walking Dead: Season Two}} Following ''Season One''{{'}}s success, a sequel was announced for release. Its first episode was released on December 17, 2013. Its final was released on August 26, 2014. =====''The Walking Dead: Season Three''===== {{main|The Walking Dead: A New Frontier}} Telltale Games confirmed that it will produce a third season of ''Walking Dead'', following the success of the first two seasons. The season began on December 20, 2016. =====''The Walking Dead: The Final Season''===== {{main|The Walking Dead: The Final Season}}In July 2017 during [[San Diego Comic Con]], Telltale Games announced that the fourth season of the series will be the final season of the game. The first of four episodes was released on August 14, 2018. ====''The Walking Dead: Social Game''==== Flash based social game on Facebook, launched in 2012 and shut down at the end of 2014. ====''Survival Instinct''==== {{main|The Walking Dead: Survival Instinct}} On July 6, 2012, [[Activision]] announced a [[first-person shooter]] based on the television series, which is being developed by [[Terminal Reality]].{{cite web |title=Activision Reveals Walking Dead First Person Shooter' |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2012/07/06/activision-reveals-walking-dead-first-person-shooter |publisher=IGN |accessdate=2012-07-06}} It was released on March 19, 2013 in [[North America]].{{cite news |title=Report: Activision Launching Walking Dead Game |url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/gamehunters/post/2012/07/report-activision-launching-walking-dead-game/1 |publisher=[[USA Today]] |accessdate=2012-07-06 |date=July 6, 2012}} It was met with negative reception. ====''The Walking Dead: Road to Survival''==== {{main|The Walking Dead: Road to Survival}} ''The Walking Dead: Road to Survival'' is a [[role-playing video game]] developed by [[Scopely]] based on the comic book series. It was released initially on the [[Android (operating system)|Android]] platform, later on [[iOS]]. Players complete various missions using teams, in exchange for further rewards, and more challenging stages. ====''The Walking Dead: No Man's Land''==== {{main|The Walking Dead: No Man's Land}} Game for Android/iOS ====''The Escapists: The Walking Dead''==== {{main|The Escapists}} ''The Escapists: The Walking Dead'' is a spin-off from ''[[The Escapists]]'', a [[Puzzle video game|puzzle]] [[role-playing video game]] about escaping prisons.{{cite web|url=https://www.team17.com/games/the-escapists-the-walking-dead/|title=The Escapists: The Walking Dead|date=}} ====''Overkill's The Walking Dead''==== {{main article|Overkill's The Walking Dead}} In August 2014, [[Starbreeze Studios]] announced that a ''The Walking Dead'' co-op [[first-person shooter]] is in development by [[Overkill Software]].{{cite web|title=Overkill's The Walking Dead announced|url=http://1337wiki.com/overkills-the-walking-dead-announced/}} The game is called ''[[Overkill's The Walking Dead]]'', and it claims to deliver a "completely new co-op experience" to ''The Walking Dead'' universe that will explore new characters and storylines. It is scheduled to launch on [[Xbox One]], [[PlayStation 4]], and [[Microsoft Windows]] in 2018. The game is being made with ''The Walking Dead'' creator [[Robert Kirkman]], who says he was certain from the first day he saw the project that it was the "co-op action game fans have been waiting for." It is also the result of a new "long-term" partnership between Starbreeze and Kirkman's company [[Skybound Entertainment|Skybound Interactive]]. This partnership will extend "into the next decade" and marks a new era for Starbreeze, the company said. ==Novels== * {{cite book|authors=[[Robert Kirkman]] & Jay Bonansinga|title=[[The Walking Dead: Rise of the Governor]]|date=October 11, 2011}} * {{cite book|authors=[[Robert Kirkman]] & Jay Bonansinga|title=[[The Walking Dead: The Road to Woodbury]]|date=October 16, 2012}} * {{cite book|authors=[[Robert Kirkman]] & Jay Bonansinga|title=[[The Walking Dead: The Fall of the Governor]]: Part One|date=October 8, 2013}} * {{cite book|author=Jay Bonansinga|title=[[The Walking Dead: The Fall of the Governor]]: Part Two|date=March 4, 2014}} * {{cite book|author=Jay Bonansinga|title=[[Robert Kirkman's The Walking Dead: Descent]]|date=October 14, 2014}} * {{cite book|author=Jay Bonansinga|title=[[Robert Kirkman's The Walking Dead: Invasion]]|date=October 6, 2015}} * {{cite book|author=Jay Bonansinga|title=[[Robert Kirkman's The Walking Dead: Search and Destroy]]|date=October 18, 2016}} * {{cite book|author=Jay Bonansinga|title=[[Robert Kirkman's The Walking Dead: Return to Woodbury]]|date=October 2017}} ==Other products== *[[McFarlane Toys]] manufactured action figures resembling the characters in the comic book for September 2011 release. revision.text:
'''Narrative transportation theory''' proposes that when people lose themselves in a story, their attitudes and intentions change to reflect that story. The mental state of narrative transportation can explain the persuasive effect of stories on people, who may experience narrative transportation when certain contextual and personal preconditions are met, as Green and Brock<ref>Green, M. C., & Brock, T. C. (2002). "In the mind's eye: Transportation-imagery model of narrative persuasion." In M. C. Green, J. J. Strange & T. C. Brock (Eds.), ''Narrative impact: Social and cognitive foundations''. (pp. 315-341). Mahwah, NJ: Lawrence Erlbaum.</ref> postulate for the transportation-imagery model. As van Laer, de Ruyter, Visconti, and Wetzels<ref name=vanlaer2014 /> elaborate further, narrative transportation occurs whenever the story receiver experiences a feeling of entering a world evoked by the narrative because of empathy for the story characters and imagination of the story plot.
== Defining the field == Deighton, Romer, and McQueen<ref name=deighton1989>Deighton, J., Romer, D., & McQueen, J. (1989). "Using drama to persuade." ''Journal of Consumer Research, 16''(3), 335-343.</ref>{{rp|335}} anticipate the construct of narrative transportation by arguing that a story invites story receivers into the action it portrays and, as a result, makes them lose themselves in the story.<ref>Nell, V. (1988). ''Lost in a book: The psychology of reading for pleasure''. New Haven, CT: Yale University.</ref> Gerrig<ref>Gerrig, R. J. (1993). ''Experiencing narrative worlds: On the psychological activities of reading''. New Haven, CT: Yale.</ref> was the first to coin the notion of narrative transportation within the context of novels. Using travel as a metaphor for reading, he conceptualizes narrative transportation as a state of detachment from the world of origin that the story receiver—in his words, the traveler—experiences because of his or her engrossment in the story, a condition that Green and Brock<ref>Green, M. C., & Brock, T. C. (2000). "The role of transportation in the persuasiveness of public narratives." ''Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 79''(5), 701-721.</ref> later describe as the story receiver's experience of being carried away by the story. Notably, the state of narrative transportation makes the world of origin partially inaccessible to the story receiver, thus marking a clear separation in terms of here/there and now/before, or narrative world/world of origin.
===Relevant features=== Most research on narrative transportation follows the original definition of the construct. Scholars in the field constantly reaffirm the relevance of three features. # Narrative transportation requires that people process stories—the acts of receiving and interpreting. # Story receivers become transported through two main components: empathy and mental imagery. Empathy implies that story receivers try to understand the experience of a story character, that is, to know and feel the world in the same way. Thus, empathy offers an explanation for the state of detachment from the world of origin that is narrative transportation. In mental imagery, story receivers generate vivid images of the story plot, such that they feel as though they are experiencing the events themselves. # When transported, story receivers lose track of reality in a physiological sense. In accordance with these features, van Laer et al.<ref name=vanlaer2014>van Laer, T., de Ruyter, K., Visconti, L. M., & Wetzels, M. (2014). "The Extended Transportation-Imagery Model: A meta-analysis of the antecedents and consequences of consumers' narrative transportation." ''Journal of Consumer Research, 40''(5), 797-817. Available at SSRN: http://ssrn.com/abstract=2033192 or doi: https://www.jstor.org/stable/10.1086/673383</ref>{{rp|799}} define narrative transportation as the extent to which # an individual empathizes with the story characters and # the story plot activates his or her imagination, which leads him or her to experience suspended reality during story reception.
===Similar constructs=== Narrative transportation is a form of experiential response to narratives and thus is similar to other constructs, such as absorption, optimal experience or [[Flow (psychology)|flow]], and [[immersion (virtual reality)|immersion]]. Yet several subtle, critical differences exist. Absorption refers to a personality trait or general tendency to be immersed in life experiences; transportation is an engrossing temporary experience. Flow is a more general construct (i.e., people can experience flow in a variety of activities), whereas transportation specifically entails empathy and mental imagery, which do not occur in flow experiences. Phillips and McQuarrie<ref>Phillips, B. J. and E. F. McQuarrie (2010). "Narrative and persuasion in fashion advertising." ''Journal of Consumer Research 37''(3), 368-392.</ref> demonstrate that immersion is primarily an experiential response to aesthetic and visual elements of images, whereas narrative transportation relies on a story with plot and characters, features that are not present in immersion.
== Narrative persuasion == Since narrative transportation's conceptualization, research has demonstrated that the transported "traveler" can return changed by the journey. Subsequent studies have confirmed that a story can engross the story receiver in a transformational experience, whose effects are strong and long-lasting. The transformation that narrative transportation achieves is persuasion of the story receiver. More specifically, van Laer et al.'s<ref name=vanlaer2014 /> literature review reveals that narrative transportation can cause affective and cognitive responses, beliefs, and attitude and intention changes. However, the processing pattern of narrative transportation is markedly different from that in well-established models of persuasion.
===Rival models=== Before 2000, dual-process models of persuasion, especially the [[elaboration likelihood model]] and [[heuristic-systematic model]], dominated persuasion research. These models attempt to explain why people accept or reject message claims. According to these models, the determination of a claim's acceptability can result from careful evaluation of the arguments presented or from reliance on superficial cues, such as the presence of an expert. Whether receivers scrutinize a message depends on the extent to which they are able and motivated to process it systematically. As important variables, these models include empathy, familiarity, involvement, and the number and nature of thoughts the message evokes. If these variables are mainly positive, the receiver's attitudes and intentions tend to be more positive; if the variables are predominantly negative, the resulting attitudes and intentions are more negative. These variables also exist in narrative persuasion.
===Differences between analytical and narrative persuasion=== Analytical persuasion and narrative persuasion differ depending on the role of involvement. In analytical persuasion, involvement depends on the extent to which the message has personally relevant consequences for a receiver's money, time, or other resources. If these consequences are sufficiently severe, receivers evaluate the arguments carefully and generate thoughts related to the arguments. Yet, as Slater<ref>Slater, M. D. (2002). "Entertainment education and the persuasive impact of narratives." In T. C. Brock, M. C. Green & J. J. Strange (Eds.), ''Narrative impact: Social and cognitive foundations'' (pp. 157-181). Mahwah, NJ: Lawrence Erlbaum.</ref>{{rp|171}} notes, even though severe consequences for stories are relatively rare, "viewers or readers of an entertainment narrative typically appear to be far more engrossed in the message." This type of involvement, or narrative transportation, is arguably the crucial determinant of narrative persuasion.
Though the dual-process models provide a valid description of analytical persuasion, they do not encompass narrative persuasion. Analytical persuasion refers to attitudes and intentions developed from processing messages that are overtly persuasive, such as most lessons in science books, news reports, and speeches. However, narrative persuasion refers to attitudes and intentions developed from processing narrative messages that are not overtly persuasive, such as novels, movies, or video games. Addressing the strength and duration of the persuasive effects of processing stories, narrative transportation is a mental state that produces enduring persuasive effects without careful evaluation of arguments. Transported story receivers are engrossed in a story in a way that neither is inherently critical nor involves great scrutiny.
===Sleeper effect=== Narrative transportation seems to be more unintentionally affective than intentionally cognitive in nature. This way of processing leads to potentially increasing and long-lasting persuasive effects. Appel and Richter<ref>Appel, M., & Richter, T. (2007). "Persuasive effects of fictional narratives increase over time." ''Media Psychology, 10''(1), 113-134.</ref>{{rp|128}} use the term "sleeper effect" to describe this paradoxical property of narrative transportation over time, which consists of a more pronounced change in attitudes and intentions and a greater certainty that these attitudes and intentions are correct.
Plausible explanations for the sleeper effect are twofold. # According to [[poststructural]] research, language's articulation in narrative format is capable not only of mirroring reality but also of constructing it. As such, stories could cause profound and durable persuasion of the transported story receiver as a result of his or her progressive internalization. When stories transport story receivers, not only do they present a narrative world but, by reframing the story receiver's language, they also durably change the world to which the story receiver returns after the transportation experience. # Research demonstrates that people analyze and retain stories differently from other information formats. For example, Deighton et al.<ref name=deighton1989 /> show that analytical advertisements stimulate cognitive responses whereas narrative advertisements are more likely to stimulate affective responses. Following this line of reasoning, van Laer et al.<ref name=vanlaer2014 />{{rp|801}} define narrative persuasion as :''the effect of narrative transportation, which manifests itself in story receivers' affective and cognitive responses, beliefs, attitudes, and intentions from being swept away by a story and transported into a narrative world that modifies their perception of their world of origin.'' : The conceptual distinction between analytical persuasion and narrative persuasion and the theoretical framework of sound interpretation of narrative persuasion both ground the extended transportation-imagery model (ETIM).
===Moderators=== ETIM contains three methodological factors that moderate the overall effect of narrative transportation, as van Laer, Feiereisen, and Visconti<ref>van Laer, T., Feiereisen, S., & Visconti, L. M. "Storytelling in the digital era: A meta-analysis of relevant moderators of the narrative transportation effect." ''Journal of Business Research''. Available at SSRN: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3156933</ref> detail. The narrative transportation effect is stronger # for stories in the commercial (vs. non-commercial) domain, # for stories by users (vs. professionals), and # for stories received alone (vs. with others).

{{Infobox film | name = Universal Classic Monsters | image = Universal_Classic_Monsters_logo.jpg | alt = | caption = Official franchise logo as displayed on home video releases | director = | producer = | writer = | starring = | music = | cinematography = | editing = | studio = [[Universal Pictures]] | distributor = | released = | runtime = | country = United States | language = | budget = | gross = | italic title = no }} '''Universal Classic Monsters''' is a phrase used to describe the [[Horror film|horror]], [[Fantasy film|fantasy]], [[Thriller (genre)|suspense]] and [[science fiction film|science fiction]] films made by [[Universal Pictures]] during the decades of the 1920s through the 1950s. They began with ''[[The Hunchback of Notre Dame (1923 film)|The Hunchback of Notre Dame]]'' and ''[[The Phantom of the Opera (1925 film)|The Phantom of the Opera]]'', both [[silent films]] starring [[Lon Chaney]]. Universal continued with [[Sound film|talkies]] including monster franchises ''[[Dracula (1931 English-language film)|Dracula]]'', ''[[Frankenstein (1931 film)|Frankenstein]]'', ''[[The Mummy (1932 film)|The Mummy]]'', ''[[The Invisible Man (1933 film)|The Invisible Man]]'', ''[[The Wolf Man (1941 film)|The Wolf Man]]'' and ''[[Creature from the Black Lagoon]]''. The films often featured [[Bela Lugosi]], [[Boris Karloff]] and [[Lon Chaney Jr.]] ==Original films== {{legend|#0022F8|'''Phantom of the Opera'''}} {{legend|#BF0404|'''Dracula'''}} {{legend|#36FF33|'''Frankenstein'''}} {{legend|#000000|'''Edgar Allan Poe'''}} {{legend|#F8C700|'''Mummy'''}} {{legend|#71E8F6|'''Invisible Man'''}} {{legend|#804903|'''Werewolf''' / '''Wolf Man'''}} {{legend|#EB4772|'''Paula, the Ape Woman''' / '''Gorilla Girl'''}} {{legend|#24077E|'''Inner Sanctum Mysteries'''}} {{legend|#7A889C|'''Creeper'''}} {{legend|#FF7502|'''Abbott & Costello'''}} {{legend|#21935E|'''Gill Man''' / '''Creature from the Black Lagoon'''}} {{legend|#FFFFFF|'''Other'''}} ===1920s=== [[File:Lon chaney sr.JPG|thumb|right|[[Lon Chaney]] in ''[[The Phantom of the Opera (1925 film)|The Phantom of the Opera]]'' (1925)]] In 1923, Universal produced the drama ''[[The Hunchback of Notre Dame (1923 film)|The Hunchback of Notre Dame]]'', starring [[Lon Chaney]] as [[Quasimodo]]. The production sets were built to evoke 15th-century Paris, including a re-creation of the [[Notre Dame de Paris]] cathedral. Chaney stars as [[Erik (The Phantom of the Opera)|The Phantom]] in 1925's horror film, ''[[The Phantom of the Opera (1925 film)|The Phantom of the Opera]]'', based on the [[The Phantom of the Opera|mystery novel]] by [[Gaston Leroux]]. The interior of the [[Opéra Garnier]] was recreated to scale and was used again in the 1943 remake with [[Claude Rains]]. {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" ! ! Film ! U.S. release date ! Actors [[Dwight Frye]] and [[Edward Van Sloan]], who played major supporting roles in both films, made several film appearances in this decade. Make-up artist [[Jack Pierce (makeup artist)|Jack Pierce]] created several monsters' make-up starting in the 1930s. ''The Mummy'', starring Karloff, was produced in 1932. This was followed by a trilogy of films based on the tales of [[Edgar Allan Poe]]: ''[[Murders in the Rue Morgue (1932 film)|Murders in the Rue Morgue]]'' (1932) starring Lugosi, ''[[The Black Cat (1934 film)|The Black Cat]]'' (1934), and ''[[The Raven (1935 film)|The Raven]]'' (1935), the latter two of which teamed Lugosi with Karloff. Universal began releasing sequels including ''[[Bride of Frankenstein]]'' (1935), ''[[Dracula's Daughter]]'' (1936) and sequels for ''[[The Invisible Man (1933 film)|The Invisible Man]]'' (1933). The first mainstream werewolf picture, ''[[Werewolf of London]]'' (1935) starring [[Henry Hull]], was not a box office triumph despite being revered by audiences today. The end of Universal’s first run of horror films came in 1936. The monster movies were dropped from the production schedule altogether and would not re-emerge for another three years. In the meantime, a theatre owner revived ''Dracula'' and ''Frankenstein'' as a resoundingly successful double feature, prompting the studio to re-release the original movies. Carroll]], [[Miles Mander]], [[Lionel Belmore]], [[Rose Hobart]] | {{N/A}} |style="text-align: center;"| 6.7 |- |} ===1940s=== During the 1940s, Universal released ''The Wolf Man'' (1941), with [[Lon Chaney Jr.]] The junior Chaney became the studio's leading monster movie actor in the 1940s, just as his father had been two decades earlier, supplanting the 1930s' Karloff and Lugosi by a wide margin in terms of the number of leading roles that he played. Chaney Jr. physically resembled his father apart from usually being somewhat overweight, which the senior Chaney never was. The studio dropped the "Jr." from the junior Chaney's billing almost immediately to confuse some in the audiences into assuming that this was the same actor. In 1943, the studio created a remake of ''[[Phantom of the Opera (1943 film)|Phantom of the Opera]]'', this time starring [[Nelson Eddy]] and [[Susanna Foster]] with Claude Rains as the Phantom. The ''Frankenstein'' and ''Wolf Man'' series continued with ''[[The Ghost of Frankenstein]]'' (1942), in which Chaney Jr. played Frankenstein's monster and Lugosi reprised his role as Ygor, and ''Frankenstein Meets the Wolf Man'' (1943) with Lugosi as the Frankenstein monster and Chaney Jr. as the Wolf Man. ''Son of Dracula'' (1943) featured Chaney Jr. in Lugosi's original role as the Count. The ''Mummy'' series was also continued with ''[[The Mummy's Hand]]'' (1940), ''[[The Mummy's Tomb]]'' (1942), ''[[The Mummy's Ghost]]'' and ''[[The Mummy's Curse]]'' (both 1944) with Chaney Jr. as the Mummy in the last three films. ''[[House of Frankenstein (1944 film)|House of Frankenstein]]'' (1944) and ''[[House of Dracula]]'' (1945) featured many of the monsters from the studio's previous films. ''Creature from the Black Lagoon'', directed by [[Jack Arnold (director)|Jack Arnold]], was released in 1954. ''Dracula'' and ''Frankenstein'' were re-released as double features in theatres, and were later broadcast in syndication on American television in 1957 as part of the ''[[Shock Theater]]'' package of Universal Monster Movies.{{cite book|last = Okuda|first = Ted|authorlink = Ted Okuda|author2=Yurkiw, Mark |title = Chicago TV Horror Movie Shows: From Shock Theatre to Svengoolie|publisher = Lake Claremont Press|year = 2007|page = 14|isbn = 978-1893121133|quote= The 'Shock!' package was sold in 142 markets. As a result, stations across the country aired a late-night ''Shock Theatre'' series to showcase these pictures.}} Magazines such as ''[[Famous Monsters of Filmland]]'' covered the monster films. Universal spent the last half of the decade issuing a number of one-shot monster films. {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" ! ! Film ! U.S. release date ! Director(s) ! Cast ! scope="row" | ''[[The Mummy (2017 film)|The Mummy]]'' | June 9, 2017 | [[Alex Kurtzman]] | [[Tom Cruise]] |style="text-align: center;"| 15% |style="text-align: center;"| 5.5 |- |} ===Dark Universe=== [[File:Dark Universe official logo.jpg|thumb|242x242px|Official logo of the Dark Universe, shared film universe as released by Universal Pictures]] Dark Universe is the term given by Universal Pictures to their planned [[cinematic universe]], which will be based on the classic Universal Monsters film series. The studio's first attempt at this universe was with the film ''[[Dracula Untold]]''. Released on October 10, 2014, with [[Luke Evans (actor)|Luke Evans]] in the [[Count Dracula|titular role]], the film was developed prior to plans for a shared universe of horror films. However, it was retooled to be a part of the franchise. The film's mixed financial and critical reception resulted in the film's future status within the franchise becoming uncertain. Since the release of ''Dracula Untold'', the connections to the shared universe have been downplayed. Universal, which had announced plans to reboot [[The Mummy (franchise)|''The Mummy'' franchise]] in 2012, decided to re-position the new installment as the first film in the series. ''[[The Mummy (2017 film)|The Mummy]]'' was set to be released in 2017 with [[Alex Kurtzman]] as director.{{cite news|last=McClintock|first=Pamela|title=Universal Stakes Out Release Date for Third Monster Movie|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/universal-stakes-release-date-third-890292|accessdate=September 24, 2016|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=May 3, 2016}}{{cite news|last=Mendelson|first=Scott|title=What Universal Must Do To Sell Its Classic Monsters Universe|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2016/07/13/what-universal-must-do-to-sell-its-classic-monsters-universe/#7772cec46b38|accessdate=September 24, 2016|publisher=''[[Forbes]]''|date=July 13, 2016}} Also, Kurtzman and [[Chris Morgan (writer)|Chris Morgan]] were announced as headlining the Dark Universe, with collaborations from [[David Koepp]] and [[Christopher McQuarrie]].{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/la-et-entertainment-news-updates-may-1495481404-htmlstory.html|title=Universal debuts its spooky new Dark Universe and its upcoming 'Bride of Frankenstein'|publisher=''LA Times''|author=Woerner, Meredith|date=May 22, 2017}} Along with the crew, Universal announced the casting of [[Russell Crowe]] as [[Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde (character)|Dr. Henry Jekyll / Mr. Edward Hyde]], [[Javier Bardem]] as the [[Frankenstein's monster|Frankenstein Monster]], and [[Johnny Depp]] as [[Griffin (The Invisible Man)|The Invisible Man]]. They would join [[Tom Cruise]] and [[Sofia Boutella]], as Nick Morton and Princess Ahmanet / The Mummy. [[Bill Condon]] was announced as the director of the franchise's ''[[Bride of Frankenstein]]'', originally set to be released on February 14, 2019.{{cite web|url=https://www.cinemablend.com/news/2423971/its-been-one-year-since-the-dark-universe-was-announced-so-what-happened|title=It's Been One Year Since The Dark Universe Was Announced, So What Happened?|publisher=Cinema Blend|author=Holmes, Adam|date=May 2018}} Even though various sources claimed that Evans' character might have at least a cameo in ''The Mummy'' or any of the upcoming films in the universe, Kurtzman denied these claims, stating that he considered the film to not be a part of the ''Dark Universe''.{{cite web|last=Trumbore |first=Dave |date=December 4, 2016 |title='The Mummy': Alex Kurtzman Confirms 'Dracula Untold' Is Not Canon, Teases Jekyll's Role |url=http://collider.com/the-mummy-universal-monsters-shared-universe/#dracula-untold |publisher=[[Collider (website)|Collider]] }} Additional rebooted versions of their characters were announced to have films in development as well including: the [[The Wolf Man (1941 film)|Wolf Man]], the [[Creature from the Black Lagoon]], the [[Phantom of the Opera (1943 film)|Phantom of the Opera]], and [[The Hunchback of Notre Dame (1923 film)|The Hunchback of Notre-Dame]]. The shared film universe's official theme music was composed by [[Danny Elfman]]. Universal has put a hold on future projects while they create a plan for future releases.{{Cite news |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/alex-kurtzman-chris-morgan-exit-universal-monsterverse-1055854 |title=Universal's 'Monsterverse' in Peril as Top Producers Exit (Exclusive) |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |publisher=[[Eldridge Industries]] |date=November 8, 2017}} [[Universal Pictures]] released an official statement reading: {{Quote|After thoughtful consideration, Universal Pictures and director [[Bill Condon]] have decided to postpone ''Bride of Frankenstein''. None of us want[s] to move too quickly to meet a release date when we know this special movie needs more time to come together. Bill is a director whose enormous talent has been proven time and again, and we all look forward to continuing to work on this film together.{{Cite news|url=http://www.denofgeek.com/uk/movies/the-mummy/53302/dark-universe-the-undignified-death-of-a-cinematic-universe|title=Dark Universe: the undignified death of a cinematic universe|work=Den of Geek|access-date=November 15, 2017|language=en}}}} By January 2018, development on the film progressed with Condon hiring a production team consisting of cinematographer [[Tobias A. When Will It Shoot?|date=January 15, 2018|publisher=''Omega Underground''|accessdate=January 15, 2018}} In May of the same year, artist Robert Vargas announced from his social media account that he had attended a meeting with the studio and will collaborate on the Dark Universe films moving forward.{{cite web|last=Schaefer|first=Sandy|url=https://screenrant.com/dark-universe-monster-movies/|title=Universal's Dark Universe Might Not Be Dead After All|date=May 18, 2018|publisher=''ScreenRant''|accessdate=May 18, 2018}} Successful horror film producer [[Jason Blum]] has publicly expressed his interest in working on the Dark Universe franchise.{{cite web|url=https://www.cbr.com/jason-blum-dark-universe-interest/|title=Spawn Producer Jason Blum Interested In Reviving Dark Universe|date=18 August 2018|publisher=}} ==See also== *''[[The Monster Squad]]'' (1987) '''Animation''' *''[[Monster Force]]'' (1994) (TV series) *''[[Van Helsing: The London Assignment]]'' (2004) (DTV) *''[[The Mummy (TV series)|The Mummy: The Animated Series]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book |last=Neibaur |first=James L. |title=The Monster Movies of Universal Studios |date=2017 |publisher=Rowman & Littlefield |isbn=978-1-44-227817-2 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=f-YrDgAAQBAJ}} ==External links== {{Commonscat|Universal Monsters film series}} * [http://www.darkuniverse.com/ Dark Universe homepage] {{Universal Monsters}} [[Category:Film series introduced in 1923]] [[Category:Universal Studios]] [[Category:Universal Classic Monsters]] [[Category:Film series]] [[Category:Horror film characters]] [[Category:Media franchises]] [[Category:Fiction about monsters]]
